p: Arginine hydrolysis is another source of NH 3. Most of the non-fermentative mollicutes and some fermentative species possess the arginine dihydrolase pathway to generate energy, which results in the production of ornithine, ATP, CO 2, and NH 3 [ 2]. A certain concentration of NH 3 can be produced by a number of arginine-utilizing mycoplasmas, such as M. hominis, M. gallinarum, M. fermentans, M. pirum, M. salivarium, M. iowae, and M. meleagridis [ 2, 102, 202, 203]. Owing to the consumption of arginine, arginine-utilizing mycoplasmas are toxic to cultured mammalian cells and may induce immunosuppression [ 202, 204].
